reasoning: The critique targets a real structural dependency in the essay’s section-3 analysis: many conclusions about whether moral trade yields near-best outcomes are conditioned on assumptions about value being linear vs bounded, diminishing returns, separability, etc. If those comparative-statics premises are badly unstable under self-modification or strategically chosen for bargaining leverage, parts of the trade/compromise optimism-pessimism story weaken. However, this is not fully central to the essay’s overall thrust (which also argues against widespread convergence via metaethics, discusses blockers, threats, power concentration, and admits high uncertainty about axiologies). Even within the trade framework, the position is already somewhat hedged/conditional, so undermining “utility-shape stability” doesn’t directly overturn the main conclusions; it mainly reduces confidence in specific case splits and forecasts about when trade works. The critique is mostly correct/plausible (strategic preference shaping and positional/identity goods are genuine complications), but it overstates with “little reason” and doesn’t argue that utility manipulation is feasible or equilibrium-dominant given commitment/identity constraints; hence moderate strength. It is clear, focused, and contains little fluff.
title: "Questionable assumptions about utility structure undermine trade benefits"
